The patient is a 62-year-old African-American male who has a history of diabetes, hypertension, and a stroke in 2002. He has right-sided weakness and numbness since that time. He has had a pacemaker placed since six months ago. Since that time, he has had numbness and burning in his hands and above his knees. He states that this has never gone away. He states that his primary concern is the burning and numbness. He states that for the last six months, he has not been able to feel anything hot in his hands. Things slip out of his hands. He denies any weakness. He has had a lot of sensation. He has had jerking in his shoulders and both hands. It has been going on for a long time but now he is noticing it more than before. He denies any tremors. He denies any neck pain. He has been using a walker because he does not feel safe walking. He has tried different medications and only oxycodone has given him some relief. He has not had any sleep problems for many years. He was transferred to a nursing home six months ago after the heart attack and pacemaker was placed. He has not had any back pain. He has not had any change in bathroom routine. He has not had any accidents or injuries before this started.
Followup.

Ms. ABC is here for followup regarding her cervical spinal stenosis. She was seen by me on 06/19/92. She had an exacerbated symptom on 06/04/92 when she lifted many objects and experienced paresthesia, weakness, and pain in her upper extremities on the right side more than the left since then. She was referred for a cervical spine MRI. She continues to have all those things like pain and weakness, and she believes that everything is coming down from her neck. She has done some physical therapy which has helped her with her neck pain, but her right hand is still feeling weak. It is difficult at times to open jars and open doors. Many times, she drops items. The right side is giving her more problems than the left. Sometimes when she is sleeping in the night, she has this sharp shooting pain and weakness that goes down her left upper hand and she feels scared after that. She is seeing Dr. X for that, and she says his methods are good and it is helping her with her neck pain, but not her hand. She has no bowel problems, back pain, or leg pain. She is not having any problems with walking or stability.
Focal radiculopathy of the cervical nerves lateral and back. No other systemic complaints.
Significant for trauma surgery.
